content.text: An IIA (also commonly called "bilateral investment treaty ("BIT") when used in a bilateral context, or "investment guarantee agreement ("IGA")) promotes greater investment flows between two signatory countries and sets out standards of protection for investments made in one country by investors from the other country.
An IIA contains obligations on the host State, which may include:
Treating foreign investors as favourably as domestic investors or foreign investors from other countries;
Treating foreign investors as favourably as domestic investors or foreign investors from other countries;
Establishing clear limits on the expropriation of investments and compensating foreign investors should expropriation occur;
Allowing foreign investors to freely transfer their capital in and out of the host State; and
Allowing foreign investors to submit investment disputes to international arbitration.
IIAs are not the same as Investment Chapters in FTAs, which generally go beyond the scope of IIAs and include other elements such as investment liberalisation and investment facilitation.

details.caption: The table below lists Singapore's FTA Investment Chapters. You may also access the other chapters of these FTAs via Enterprise Singapore's FTA webpage.

content.text: The amendments from the 3rd Review entered into force on 1 December 2017.
The CSFTA Upgrade Protocol entered into force on 16 Oct 2019.
Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP)
The 1st Review was concluded on 1 November 2007.
The 2nd Review was concluded on 19 March 2007.
The ANZSCEP Upgrade entered into force on 1 Jan 2020.
Countries from EFTA are Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland.

AHKIA entered into force for Singapore, Hong Kong, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand and Viet Nam on 17 June 2019; for Malaysia on 13 October 2019; Philippines on 12 May 2020; Indonesia on 4 July 2020; and Brunei on 20 Oct 2020.
The amendments from the AJCEP First Protocol entered into force for Japan, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Singapore, Thailand and Viet Nam on 1 Aug 2020 and Brunei on 1 Oct 2020.

contentPageHeader.summary: Singapore's International Investment Agreements promote investment flows between the signatory countries. Find out more here.
